title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
Only RTC region and CMOS registries of PCH are powered from PPVRTC_G3H.
Check PP3V3_SUS presence.

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message: Could be thunderbolt circuit, could be corrosion under SMC, bad BIOS traces, firewire chip... that board is terrible looking.

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
"all 4 RTC signals"
Almost always, people posting only two.
As the other two don't have "RTC" in the name, nobody pay atention.
But schematic clearly show them connected to PCH's RTC block...

Y5010 oscillates?
Do you have 3V3_S5 present?
Check S5_PWRGD and PM_DSW_PWRGD.
PM_BATLOW_L is also low?

message:

PCH_INTVRMEN_L 2.201v

3V3_S5 0v

S5_PWRGD 0V PM_DSW_PWRGD 0V

PM_BATLOW_L 0.017v

Put board in ultrasonic again earlier since liquid damage was so bad. Before board was drawing 0.20amps and now the board is using 0.142 amps and u7200 is very hot. I already replaced it but still very hot

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
"Y5010 is not oscillating and is at a steady 1.578V"
I mean oscillates on o-scope...
1.5V is close to normal value, but DC voltage cannot assure you for proper oscillation.

"3V3_S5 0v"
This doesn't depend by PCH, is controlled by SMC.

If U7200 heats after UC, probably some traces got broken, or some components fall out.
UC without sweep function is a danger for logic board, if you let it various minutes in the same position; read about "hot spot" for cavitation.
Check for any short (L7220/60 maybe) and missing caps (C7220/60?) around U7200.

Never power up a board after replacing of a hot component.
Think first, why was getting hot???
There could be other reason...

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
I don't have a o-scope

Do not have any shorts and no missing caps around u7200

what else to check?

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3

If changed and still the same, obviously is not the culprit.
Check for short/low resistance on VREG3/5, VIN, VREF, L7220/60...
Post its voltages.

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
"l7260 0.036"
That's no good.
Remove power and wait 20s before measure diode mode on board...
Measure both directions, red and black at ground.

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
0.007 in diode mode is aprox 10-15 ohms in 200ohm scale.
Something is strange with your measures...

Put red probe on ground and touch the coil with black probe; note the value.
Invert the probes and note the other (reverse) value.

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
Remove F7040 and see if get correct voltage at C7040.
If OK, then the problem is not on the power supply; which seems to be correct, but is better to discard 100%.

Looks like a short around U7200, or the chip itself.
Check Q7260 and high-side of Q7220 for short.
Also check at VREG3/5 and VREF outputs...

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message: VREG5 is probably shorted to GND causing the chip to heat up. Check resistance to GND.

title: 820-2936a missing pp5v_s3
message:
Start from zero...
Disconnect everything from the board; leave only magsafe connected, nor even RAM is needed.
If U7200 gets VIN and EN0, it should generate VREF, VREG3 and VREG5.

If ENTRIP2 has 0.75V, PP3V3_S5 should also appear.
Both EN0 and ENTRIP2 are controlled by SMC_PM_G2_EN; so should appear at the same moment.

If ENTRIP2 has 0.9V, PP5V_S3 should also appear.
This is controlled by PM_SLP_S4_L.

Low voltage at VREG5 can only be caused by U7200 itself, or external component sinking to much current.
Start removing chips connected there.
R5805 will isolate U5805 area.
Q7840 will separate PP5V_SUS; you can also check for short directly there.
C7273, near U7200, need to be removed for checking. Also U/C7801 need remove to check.
